qas.question: An approved HCP results in what being issued for the species?

answers.text: allow incidental takes for varying amounts of time

qas.question: How is the public made aware of ITP applications?

answers.text: A notice of the permit application action is published in the Federal Register

qas.question: How long does the public have to comment on ITP applications?
What is issued if an HCP is rejected?
How long does an HCP last for?
What state is San Bruno in?
What do not apply when a permit is issued?
What entity publishes the HCP for public comment?

context: The person or organization submits a HCP and if approved by the agency (FWS or NMFS), will be issued <a0_0>an Incidental <b4_0>Take Permit (ITP)<b4_0/><a0_0/> which allows a certain number of "takes" of the listed species. The permit may be revoked at any time and can <a1_0>allow incidental takes for <b5_0>varying amounts of time<b5_0/><a1_0/>. For instance, the San Bruno Habitat Conservation Plan/ Incidental Take Permit is good for 30 years and the Wal-Mart store (in <b6_0>Florida<b6_0/>) permit expires after one year. Because the permit is issued by a federal agency to a private party, it is a federal action-which means <b7_0>other federal laws<b7_0/> can apply, such as the National Environmental Policy Act or NEPA. <a2_0>A notice of the permit application action is published in the <b8_0>Federal Register<b8_0/><a2_0/> and a public comment period of <a3_0>30 to 90 days<a3_0/> begins.
